Posted: February 12, 2014
												Blood Money is a fine and worthy follow up to the older Hitman games. In comparsion, this game feels more like a casual breezethrough on normal difficulty. Though the levels are often complex, and the AI occasionally inconsistant, for the most part the game will hardly frustrate you to the levels of Hitman 2. This is a good thing, as it makes the experience more enjoyable, and you can always play at more difficult levels if you want to. Blood Money offers more reasonable ways to kill your target. Sedatives and poision work better, and agent 47 himself controls tighter then before, allowing you to actually make us of the small windows of time you are given. For a newcomer, this is the preferred place to start, as the story sort of takes a hold of itself and moves into more interesting territory (though don't expect to be rock n rolled with sympathy for 47). Blood Money is great fun, though veterens may find it too simplistic, its great to see the improvements on the series over time.

Posted: November 16, 2015
												This is probably my favorite game. I'm not a huge gamer but even I can appreciate the challange Hitman: Blood Money presents. The disguise in Absolution was broken, and the 'instinct' mechanism was too over powering but because of the flawed desguise system you needed it. This game keeps it simple. The level design is perfect, even though its sand box, it's not confusing, and easy to navigate while keeping a natural and convincing environment. The story isn't centrpeice and the cut scenes are skippable which for casual players is a plus. The plot really is quite generic although around the late middle and end it gets quite interesting. The most enthralling moments though are taking out your targets with a poison, blowing up/shooting a light fixture to land on him, getting personal and choking him piano wire or just being a straight savage and decimating the whole area. The point system at the end of each level is rewarding as well and makes sense which makes completeing the mission fun no matter which route you take.This game is amazing, it is unarguable the best Hitman in the series. So much replay value, I wouldn't hesitate. If you have a spare 10 bucks and its burning a hole in your pocket, Hitman: Blood money is an investment, not a waste. Definitely buy this one it is so worth it.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2013
												Oh! yeah... Mr. 47 is back in this new installment were the story follows the life of professional hitman Agent 47, as narrated in cut scenes by a former director of the FBI to a journalist who is interviewing him. The wheelchair-using ex-director recounts how his agency tracked 47 over a two-year period (but enough of the plot, don't want to spoil it for you).Lots of improvements were done to the gameplay adding more simplified commands and ways to do stuff while using 47. The disguise works better than the previous games and using the split screens give you more insight of important events happening in each of the assassinations. As before there is more than 1 way to complete the missions, but this time every action you do has a consequence for the next mission, because if you go into a mission gunning everyone in your way, in the next mission the guards or the enemy will be able to recognize you quickly; that makes getting the "Silent Assassin" rating (keep in mind you will need patience and well-timed moves to get this rating) something critical, not just because you will get a lot of money for every mission (which will be handy to purchase weapons and upgrades). Plus you get to experience some random and funny events during the mission (won't spoil any of them, but let's just say you can see Mr. 47 dressed as a clown... XD).Graphics are awesome and a superb improvement from their previous games in the series. Music is amazing and it really makes you feel like you are in a movie.If you played the previous games in the series, probably you will like this one a lot and if you beat it once with random rating; want more? Get the "Silent Assassin" rating in all missions, I assure you will give you a good challenge and it will be rewarding!...

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												IO is the master of immersion. Blood Money truly makes you FEEL like Agent 47 - cool, calculating, and deadly. Blood Money represents a form of game design that developers have sadly moved away from - the open sandbox. Yeah, we have Saints' Row, GTA, Skyrim, etc, but those titles don't manage to so masterfully pace themselves and create a game that is unmatched in its style. Barring the brief, horribly linear tutorial mission, you have the ability to go about EVERY SINGLE mission afterwards in your own way, using your own style, crafting your own anecdote. Blood Money represents the Hitman franchise as a whole through its near perfectness. You'll be doing yourself a favour if you purchase this game - it'll spoil you so well with its freedom that you'll emerge from its grasp hating linearity and setpieces. Well worth the cash. Well done, IO.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												I had a lot of fun with this game. A lot more than I expected to, given that I am not a fan of the original Hitman. This one felt much more polished and easier to understand.Graphics: For its time, it looks great. The environments look pretty and the character models are quite good. Some of the landscapes, like the Vegas city scape, had me saying "wow", even though the game is nearly 10 years old.Story: The Hitman games are not known for having incredibly gripping storylines, at least in my experience. The story was better than I expected it to be, but is probably still the weakest part of the game. Fortunately, you can look past it because just about everything else is great.Level Design: Yes, yes, and yes. This game is everything I've ever wanted out of a sneaking game in terms of level design. The levels are very big, usually containing at least 4 large floors with numerous maps and PLENTY of ways to complete the missions. Some are obvious, and some require a bit of intuition. The game forces you to explore the whole level and figure out how to complete it on your own. It doesn't baby you and tell you what to do. I will admit, I had to resort to walkthroughs at times, but when I managed to complete the level my own way, it was incredibly satisfying.Gameplay: My issue with every Hitman game has always been clunky controls. This one is no exception. At least the games are consistent in that sense. Absolution has the smoothest controls so far, but it's still not quite on the same level as something like Assassin's Creed. But, obviously, that is an entirely different style of game.Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and would reccommend it to anyone who enjoys badass, intuitive, sneaking based games! 8/10

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Strategic freedom all over the place. Plan your own kills, complete the levels on your own terms, and when all that fails (which it will) improvise (although improvising usually comes in the form of whipping out a gun and mowing down anyone who stands in your way)...Seriously, though. Hitman: Blood Money allows you to do everything your way. It throws you into a big level filled with a load of NPCs and then lets you off your leash. You'll usually have no idea what you're doing at first, but killing your target is still pretty easy.Then, you go back through the game, this time trying to achieve Silent Assassin ranking on every level and suddenly you have to piece together some detailed plans and try to kill your target in the most secretive of ways.My main complaint about this game is really just the fact that weapons lack bass. It sounds like you're shooting a pellet gun. Other than that, it wins in pretty much every aspect.It's also extremely satisfying to exploit the system. For example, a mission involved me taking the disguise of a delivery boy and then delivering a case of diamonds to my target. Directly after the case is delivered, a security guard in the room with me will escort me out of the building, taking me away from my target. This was intended from the beginning, but with a little bit of ingenuity you can devise a plan so simple that it's brilliant. All I have to do is merely close the door on the way out of the room and whilst the security guard can't see me, hide behind the door. Now he opens it and has lost sight of me, so I throw a coin into the corner of the room so that he'll walk towards it, then descend upon him and sedate him.Now, suddenly, nobody is keeping watch over me. My genius plan has worked and I'm in the building unharmed. Now I can simply walk right back into the room where I left down the diamond case and shoot my target with a silenced pistol. Simple as that.That right there is just one tiny example of the kind of plans you have to form to get a high ranking in a level. It grows much bigger, from taking the disguise a priest at a wedding and then whipping out your Silverballers mid-marriage to blow the groom away, from dropping a chandelier onto a moving target using an explosive, the game has some brilliant strategic freedom for you to indulge in.Get this. Now.*slams desk*

												Holy Mary Mother of Jesus this game is good. Possibly one of the finest examples of level design EVER. Blood Money is a rare type of game wherein a good deal of the fun is in giving yourself a goal or challenge. You could start with getting the best rank, or no witnesses, but eventually you'll want to move on to sillier things and be amazed at how well the game facilitates it. It's like the game knew everything anyone could possibly want out of it. No silent weapons? No explosives? ONLY explosives? No witnesses? ALL THE WITNESSES!? Anything is possible in this game; it's so close to perfect it's incredible. I would highly recommend getting Blood Money and NOT Absolution. I can't emphasize that enough. And hey, even the story isn't that bad!

												Sometimes a game doesn't need a deep, complex, and intresting story. Sometimes a game doesn't need crisp, smooth, and polished combat. No sometimes a game needs to give you choice and my friends Blood Money does just that. Hitman: Blood Money puts you back in the well polished shoes of Agent 47 and tasks you to perform several hits and other assorted mission (That still involve killing people) of course once you are dropped into a mission a thought may cross your mind, "What am I supposed to do?" And that is the beauty of it. Players may approach there objective in any way they see fit, for example you could go Rambo on your targets, using a number of disguises to stalk your prey, or stealthly set up sinister traps ranging from poisoning food in some missions to swapping a prop gun at an opera for a real one. Hitman is a must play for those who call themselves stealth game fans or for anyone wanting a new fresh experince.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												By far and away, the best-designed game in the series.  For Blood Money, the folks at IO created an interesting mesh of stealth and puzzle game that fits perfectly with the series' theme.  Instead of just running and gunning, each mission, told in a neat retrospective wrapping story, presents players with multiple routes for success without a single hand-holding session to guide them.  A lot of the game is simply maneuvering 47 to places where he can properly observe the patterns as people and targets go about their daily business.  The locations are fantastic and back then, some of the visuals were mind-blowing - Mardis Gras in particular.Why IO abandoned this design philosophy for Absolution is beyond me, but forget about that game.  That game is a travesty of a follow-up after Blood Money.  If you have never played a Hitman game before, forget about Absolution.  Pick this one up.  It's cheaper and it's much, much better.

												This game is a murder sandbox. But not the kind of murder that is run n' gun (allthough you can in fact do that), this is a game filled with cold calculated murder that can be acheived numerous ways. Sure you can kill your targets with a small selection of scripted methods, but the true fun comes from experimentation. Wan't to kill a woman by throwing a coin at the skylight? Go ahead, try it. Want to grab an actor from his room, drag him to the catwalk, and throw him onto the stage when he is called? It's a bit sloppy, but try it! Wanna just walk up to a drug lord, shoot him in the head, and run away? You will probobly die but try it! I have never had so much fun going back to old missions in a game and applying self imposed challenges, or just going with with no objective and goofing off. This is the funnest and goofiest hitman game in the series, and for the price, its a steal.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												This game may be older, but it is considered a cult classic to this day. The Hitman titles before this one are the perfect brew of quirky, challenging stealth and humor. However, this one is regarded as the best in the franchise because it not only had the elements of the first couple games, but implemented a disguise system, upgraded accident system and above all: unleashed the freedom of sandbox gameplay (something the newest title "Absolution" did not particularily have). Basic Overview: You are one of the world's best assassins who was created in a laboratory as a killing machine, plain and simple. Your alias: 47. You work for a smoke and mirrors agency under a mysterious woman named "Diana" who provides you with targets and mission details. The targets are larger than life, often rediculous and have prices on their heads that can set any average joe up for the rest of his days. The cleaner the hit, the more money in it for you. Your shady bosses have some international pull so weapons and certain things can be planted on the job site to make your work easier. Other than that, you do how you see fit. You can go in there gunning if you think you're strong enough to overpower your target's security. If you don't fancy getting shot, you can sneak in wearing a disguise, infiltrate your mark's hideout, then give them the drop when nobody's looking. There's also the option of say, rigging a chandeliear to fall on somebody's noggin slap-stick style or making someone have an "unfortunate accident" by falling over a railing. The possibilities are endless! However, whatever inconspicous things you do such as leaving evidence, getting seen by witnesses or getting your cover blown can effect how easily you're detected in future missions. You aren't the only one in the Blood Money game either, any job could be a set up! Are you willing to risk the odds for the payout?Cons: The controls seem rather "stiff" and not fluid, especially when moving slowly or pivoting on the spot. There are sometimes annoying glitches such as people falling through floors/doors/walls when pushed and alerting your enemies. The AI can be extremely unintelligent and rag-doll glitchy which can bring some comedy into the gameplay, however, they are crack shots and can be extremely unforgiving, especially when glitched within a close proximity to 47s character. This game is sometimes not compatible in default settings with certain hardware/Windows versions and may crash/not run at all, but a simple patch and or resolution change often fixes these issues. Some level design may seem lazy in parts, but it's still nice to explore your whole environment, which is part of the Hitman experience. Overall: I give this game an 8.5/10 given it is one of the funest games I have ever played and I still play it from time to time. I reccomend this game if you like stealth games, but you want a hint of free rome and added options in there. If you like linear stealth action, I would recommend the next title in the franchise "Absolution". The next game, simply called "Hitman" boasts it will bring the sandbox element back into its gameplay. I think anything like Absolution's systems with Blood Money's freedom it would be a win/win! Fingers crossed!

Posted: August 1, 2015
												Strategic freedom all over the place. Plan your own kills, complete the levels on your own terms, and when all that fails (which it will) improvise (although improvising usually comes in the form of whipping out a gun and mowing down anyone who stands in your way)...Seriously, though. Hitman: Blood Money allows you to do everything your way. It throws you into a big level filled with a load of NPCs and then lets you off your leash. You'll usually have no idea what you're doing at first, but killing your target is still pretty easy.Then, you go back through the game, this time trying to achieve Silent Assassin ranking on every level and suddenly you have to piece together some detailed plans and try to kill your target in the most secretive of ways.My main complaint about this game is really just the fact that weapons lack bass. It sounds like you're shooting a pellet gun. Other than that, it wins in pretty much every aspect.It's also extremely satisfying to exploit the system. For example, a mission involved me taking the disguise of a delivery boy and then delivering a case of diamonds to my target. Directly after the case is delivered, a security guard in the room with me will escort me out of the building, taking me away from my target. This was intended from the beginning, but with a little bit of ingenuity you can devise a plan so simple that it's brilliant. All I have to do is merely close the door on the way out of the room and whilst the security guard can't see me, hide behind the door. Now he opens it and has lost sight of me, so I throw a coin into the corner of the room so that he'll walk towards it, then descend upon him and sedate him.Now, suddenly, nobody is keeping watch over me. My genius plan has worked and I'm in the building unharmed. Now I can simply walk right back into the room where I left down the diamond case and shoot my target with a silenced pistol. Simple as that.That right there is just one tiny example of the kind of plans you have to form to get a high ranking in a level. It grows much bigger, from taking the disguise a priest at a wedding and then whipping out your Silverballers mid-marriage to blow the groom away, from dropping a chandelier onto a moving target using an explosive, the game has some brilliant strategic freedom for you to indulge in.Get this. Now.*slams desk*

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
You are the premier assassin, Agent 47. Infiltrate > Observe > Execute > ExfiltrateAn amazing and well-designed game with a unique identiy & gameplay style. Hide in plain sight. Execute your objective(s) with extraordinary freedom of approach. Avoid collateral damage and assassinate your target/s.Having played Absolution before Blood Money, I told myself to lower my expectations - regarding graphics as well as how great the gameplay would be - due to its dated nature and how much people hated Absolution but upon starting the game I was downright blown away and the hate quickly made sense. I would say that if you have interest in this title definitely do get whenever you can (I got it during a sale :/ ).I'll try to dispense with my usual extremely long reviews (if possible... mostly 'cause I'm lazy ATM) & list the features that make this game standout, give it high replayability value & possibly make you regret the direction the franchise is now going in (really though, don't hate!) I gotta admit I didn't play that many levels yet but I feel I've seen much of what BM has to offer.Graphics are not nearly as bad as expected. Game looks better than the preview images on the store page made me think but it's not heavy at all and you shouldn't have a problem running it (hopefully).Customizable, upgradable inventory and fully (sexy, British) voiced  briefing before each mission. Large items cannot be hidden in your suit (like the sniper rifle - which has a carrying case - or any long rifle). Use pistols, rifles, a wire, bombs, coins and other items. Plus, you can use items/weapons you find during the mission. Weapons are not 'glued' to you; they can be discarded, switched or temporarily hidden out of sight during a mission.Medium-sized maps of various sizes and complexity. Critically acclaimed level designs that look very natural/realistic & artistic and aren't riddled with meaningless things like doors that don't function and pretty items that are glued to their surface.Each level (after the relatively linear tutorial level) is an open sandbox featuring a large compound where every NPC is going on with their life in real time. There are practically no checkpoints needed to trigger the next scripted event or spawn the next set of NPCs, instead as soon as you are in your starting position in the map the target is in his place, possibly moving around or doing something, and it's up to you to observe your environment and plan your strategy or improvise as you move along.A very minimalistic UI that shows nothing more than necessary and allows for more engaging gameplay (pretty much only minimap & equiped item is constantly visible, if I remember corectly). The inventory key must be pressed to view & select your item and the map key allows you to view the different levels & track enemy & target movements.Hide in plain sight. Start your mission in well-populated areas and walk among the crowds and/or take on various disguises that grant different levels of authority in different areas. Observe>infiltrate>execute>exfiltrate (order isn't that critical...)Every action has its consequences. The score system makes for an arcade-like experience where every piece of evidence you leave behind - every dead body, every stray bullet, every eye witness, every camera video recording and every assassin suit you leave behind when first changing disguises - affect your score/rating/rank, which is presented to you in an ever classy newspaper article detailing the findings of the police in the following day along with a sketch of your face depending on eye witness testimony (you're gonna want nothing more than a question mark on that face), and your notoriety which ranges from 1-100. Your rating tells you your skill level and your notoriety accumulates until you pay off witnesses or suffer your face becoming more recognizable. Therefore, you won't get scenarios that FORCE you to get into a gunfight or kill someone other than your target, although it's an option.Spend money from completed assignments (which changes according to performance) on upgrading equipment, buying new ones or paying off witnesses to reduce notoriety.The game features a subtle story that progresses very slowly during cutscenes after your missions, not affecting or intruding on your gameplay. You are simply an assassin doing commisions.The game features several difficulty levels that primarily affect how many times you can save during a mission, i.e. how many 'checkpoints' you can manually create, if any. It also affects whether the agency will 'help' you in your mission, leaving a 'gift' for you within the compound that is visible on the map for you to find. Possibly the mini-map can also be removed, I don't remember ATM :/Once you're found out during a mission, it's very difficult to regain notoriety again and continue your mission (unless you kill everybody?); you will likely die, return to previous save/checkpoint or restart the mission :/There's no real background music while you're playing, except in the main menu.The Hitman experienceExperience freedom of approach that tests your skill as well as your creativity, persistent NPCs that carry out their duties diligently or roam the compounds freely' immersive mission that aren't over until they're over; even after taking out your target you'll have to be careful and diligent until you successfully escape. Carefully plan your strike by observing the bahaviours of the people around you or be quick witted and improvise as you see fit.You can essentially make your way a kilometer deep into the compound, climb 3 stories (using the stairs I mean), plan an assassination, walk far away and execute it (e.g. using remote mine, sniper etc) or watch it execute itself (e.g. using a land mine). This is one feature I cannot say many titles have and it's well-executed.Even the TUTORIAL level has a degree of replayability/variety. IIRC, the target can be shot, beaten to death, chocked or blown  up. In his office you can see that he's a baseball fan and he has a signed baseball bat framed on the wall. While he was crying and begging, I broke the glass, took the baseball bat and batted his head :D Mwahahaha~I think all Eidos Interactive/Square Enix needs to do for another good title like this is make more cool levels across the world, add a dynamic whether and time system (maybe with the personnel sometimes changing shifts), improve graphics and maybe add a tad bit more realism in the gameplay with regards to real espionage here and there.damnitslongafterall

												Well what can I say? Another amazing Hitman game....Game has the same concept as the previous titles but;-Weapon Customization: All ICA weapons can be customized with various attachments.-Notoriety ratings: After completing a mission, depending on how well you cover your tracks you will either gain or stay hidden in the publics' eye. There is a newspaper after the mission that describes how the assassination played out(weapons used, how many killed, how many witnesses. Be sloppy and miss? The editors will say you are a shotty marksman. Kill the target, and make it an accident? The editors will disclose it how you made it seem. etc.-Money system: Depending on your rating you will be awarded a sum of cash. Failure to retrieve your iconic suit, or weapons will result in a loss in the final income.Now onto the general stuff;There aren't as many missions like Hitman 2, but since there are so many ways to kill in this game, there is some replay value. You can also play the many difficulties if you want a challenege once beating it on easier difficulties. The graphics have been enhanced and the level design is fluid, there is no more "dead ends" like in Hitman 2 USSR levels. The soundtrack is done by the amazing Jesper Kyd and does not dissapoint. Each level has their own unique ambient music which sets the mood every time. They have added melee combat in this game which is a plus, you can now disarm enemies and take their gun/knock them out(makes a lot of noise so use only when you have to).With all the nice said and done onto the problems. Sometimes there are annoying glitches that send guards running in the room you are in when you silently kill your target, I don't know if this is intentional for scripted reasons or an error in the patrol coding. It happens sometimes but not enough to be bothersome unless you are trying to get SA everytime, just hit restart and try again. There are some clipping errors, or times civilians are walking in eachother.Other than that this is the same cookie cutter formula for a Hitman game, just additional content and ways to kill!I would recommend this game if you are a fan of the Hitman series.

												DO NOT BE PUT OFF BY THIS GAME'S DEMO.I hate typing in all capitals, but any potential buyer of this needs to see that. The demo for Hitman Blood Money is utter tripe. I'll admit that, and it put me off too. However, when I finally got around to buying this, and made it through a few missions, it was clear that this game was something special. It's so open and fun - you attempt the missions on your own terms, not forced into approaching them in any way other than your own, unique style. These levels are varied too, with sizes ranging from huge casinos to cosy little suburban neighbourhoods. There are so many novel and interesting ways of completing your objectives that this game has a lot of replay value. The situations this game creates are always tense, but often hilarious. When I play Hitman, I enter a state of sadistic glee. Absolutely one of my favourite games. Not many sequels top the original game, but in my opinion, this is the best of the series. If it's on sale, buy it.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												Honestly - a better Hitman than the more recent titles. This was the one to have, that did its franchise the best. If Grand Theft Auto is a sandbox game, Hitman was the modern sandbox assasin game. It had a multitude of ways to get the job done, varying from actually being an assassin to gunning down a neighbourhood dressed in a clown suit. Both have increasingly tougher restrictions ("it's harder and harder to be the perfect assassin" vs "there's way too many armed FBI agents to rambo as Big Bird in the open" kind of deal). It struggled, though, with some wonky controls pitted against tough, sometimes unforgiving, level design. That's important knowledge to evaluate #3, Blood Money. H:BM took the crappy combat system and polished it, heavily, to the point you can really enjoy a good firefight and be a badass. As opposed to retreating to a room and gunning the door until the entire level was clear. The Early Warning System lets you know full well when you're blowing your cover in advance, giving you the heads-up alerts that, in Hitman 1, you literally had to discover by screwing up and restarting. Finally, it remans very, very Hitman - Fat, shy, girls do not exist, levels are wacky, stealth is awesome, guns are awesomer, RAGDOLL PHYSICS ARE LOLZ. Graphically, this game still works without hurting your eyes, and I'd recommend a try

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Well what can I say? Another amazing Hitman game....Game has the same concept as the previous titles but;-Weapon Customization: All ICA weapons can be customized with various attachments.-Notoriety ratings: After completing a mission, depending on how well you cover your tracks you will either gain or stay hidden in the publics' eye. There is a newspaper after the mission that describes how the assassination played out(weapons used, how many killed, how many witnesses. Be sloppy and miss? The editors will say you are a shotty marksman. Kill the target, and make it an accident? The editors will disclose it how you made it seem. etc.-Money system: Depending on your rating you will be awarded a sum of cash. Failure to retrieve your iconic suit, or weapons will result in a loss in the final income.Now onto the general stuff;There aren't as many missions like Hitman 2, but since there are so many ways to kill in this game, there is some replay value. You can also play the many difficulties if you want a challenege once beating it on easier difficulties. The graphics have been enhanced and the level design is fluid, there is no more "dead ends" like in Hitman 2 USSR levels. The soundtrack is done by the amazing Jesper Kyd and does not dissapoint. Each level has their own unique ambient music which sets the mood every time. They have added melee combat in this game which is a plus, you can now disarm enemies and take their gun/knock them out(makes a lot of noise so use only when you have to).With all the nice said and done onto the problems. Sometimes there are annoying glitches that send guards running in the room you are in when you silently kill your target, I don't know if this is intentional for scripted reasons or an error in the patrol coding. It happens sometimes but not enough to be bothersome unless you are trying to get SA everytime, just hit restart and try again. There are some clipping errors, or times civilians are walking in eachother.Other than that this is the same cookie cutter formula for a Hitman game, just additional content and ways to kill!I would recommend this game if you are a fan of the Hitman series.

												Everybody goes on and on about this game about how good it is, and I am one of them. Improved graphics, good story with extremely memorable levels, the ability to upgrade weapons (not all of them though, which I thought was something they should have allowed), multiple ways to complete a level, and something that I feel is the best addition to the game: it allows room for error. 												This is an amazing game. You have complete freedom to complete the levels however you would like. You can go in with a mission and immediately start shooting, or you can take the approach I favor, and go in and never get seen. In this game, you become agent 47, a bald, elite Hitman clone. The goal of every mission is to take out a target or sometimes several. Sometimes, you must protect your target. Other times you must retrieve suitcases full of diamonds as well. You do all this by sneaking around, taking disguises, and silently taking everyone in your way out. The gameplay is awesome.However, the graphics leave a little to be desired, and the Glacier engine is infamous for being difficult to mod.Other things I liked: you are able to modify your weapons. This means buying nicer scopes, silencers, lockpicks, and larger clips. I also liked how funny some of the 'easter eggs' are. For example, you can knock out FBI agents by pouring ether on a bottle of panties, or poison doughnuts in order to take out a surveillance van. Overall, its a good game. Its by far the best Hitman game.

												This game, my friends.THIS GAME.It's- it's like.It's like when your parents promise you the puppy that you've always wanted for your birthday but then your birthday finally comes and you just get a stuffed animal because they don't love you and you feel all disappointed afterwards. So you break into the local animal shelter at night and steal the puppy you want. Then your parents find out what you did the next day and legally arrange for your disownment. So you're then sent to live with your uncle, Mark, and his little adopted son, David. You feel sad because your puppy was confiscated by child services and David keeps stealing your stuff. Before you do, however, the neighbor's daughter gives you her puppy for Christmas because her parents are going to put it down if she doesn't get rid of it. 												One of my favorite games of all time. The stealth is spot-on for a game. By that I mean, you couldn't call any of the artificial intelligence "intelligent," by any means. It's infinitely exploitable, but it IS very clear how enemies are perceiving you. That lets you just have fun in the world. Trick bad guys into doing stupid things. Commit obvious murders and get away with them. Be the last man standing and still have them have NO idea who could have possibly done such a thing. They're not *stupid* - you have to be careful to not be observed - but it's still a hell of a lot of fun to play in the game's sandboxes full of wonderful murder toys.And the music. The music is glorious. Jesper Kyd at his very best.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												This is an amazing game. You have complete freedom to complete the levels however you would like. You can go in with a mission and immediately start shooting, or you can take the approach I favor, and go in and never get seen. In this game, you become agent 47, a bald, elite Hitman clone. The goal of every mission is to take out a target or sometimes several. Sometimes, you must protect your target. Other times you must retrieve suitcases full of diamonds as well. You do all this by sneaking around, taking disguises, and silently taking everyone in your way out. The gameplay is awesome.However, the graphics leave a little to be desired, and the Glacier engine is infamous for being difficult to mod.Other things I liked: you are able to modify your weapons. This means buying nicer scopes, silencers, lockpicks, and larger clips. I also liked how funny some of the 'easter eggs' are. For example, you can knock out FBI agents by pouring ether on a bottle of panties, or poison doughnuts in order to take out a surveillance van. Overall, its a good game. Its by far the best Hitman game.

												I played many games but Hitman series, are one of my favourate!!!  The reason? The blood money is the best one in all series. Unlike others, I only touch the walkthough after I finish the mission. Posted: October 6, 2014
												The best Hitman game. Ever. While it did change some gameplay aspects from the earlier games and doesn't look amazing like the latest, it's still the greatest. Why? I'll tell you why.-It's got a pretty good story, for starters. I mean, it's not as deep as the story in let's say Hitman: Contracts, but it really does  make the player ask questions for most of the game. "Who is this ex-CIA guy in the wheelchair?" and  "Why is he so interested in 47?", and so then the story adds up to that near the end.-The gameplay is possibly the greatest designed out of all the Hitman games. Definitely takes a hold of the open world and each character plays a moving part in a large level. As the assassin, you have to learn and observe every of these moving parts before you can make your own move and make sure you don't screw everything up. You always have to come prepared for the next mission, and it always feels so much more rewarding when you accomplish Silent Assassin rating on a level (and then shows a newspaper headline starring the mysterious person known as you!).-I can't say much for the visuals (the game is several years old, so I'm not complaining) but they don't really matter in a game as amazing as this.-The musical score has to be the most amazing thing to ever exist. I mean, seriously, Jesper Kyd is one of the video game music gods among Kelly Bailey and Michael McCann. He knows how to capture each moment in the game with a perfect musical tone settling it. My favorite track from the game has to be Apocalypse (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VGlhoUE86gA) after you eliminate a target perfectly and that evil grin appears on your face.Overall, I could say it's a 9.5/10 (I wish it was longer though, at least another mission or two!)

												DO NOT BE PUT OFF BY THIS GAME'S DEMO.I hate typing in all capitals, but any potential buyer of this needs to see that. The demo for Hitman Blood Money is utter tripe. I'll admit that, and it put me off too. However, when I finally got around to buying this, and made it through a few missions, it was clear that this game was something special. It's so open and fun - you attempt the missions on your own terms, not forced into approaching them in any way other than your own, unique style. These levels are varied too, with sizes ranging from huge casinos to cosy little suburban neighbourhoods. There are so many novel and interesting ways of completing your objectives that this game has a lot of replay value. The situations this game creates are always tense, but often hilarious. When I play Hitman, I enter a state of sadistic glee. Absolutely one of my favourite games. Not many sequels top the original game, but in my opinion, this is the best of the series. If it's on sale, buy it.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to submit, I've decided to just leave it on my Backloggery page.Gameplay: As with every other stealth game I do these reviews on, I feel the need to point out that I'm not good at stealth. At all. Fortunately, Hitman: Blood Money takes stealth in a bit different of a direction. While you can always spend your days creeping around corners and walking very close to armed thugs but not too close otherwise they'll notice you, you also have the option to disguise yourself. I tended to go for the latter more than the former, since as mentioned earlier, I'm not good at all at stealth. Of course, there are consequences to both sides. From these two initial decision factors a lot of the missions become surprisingly non-linear, allowing for a multitude of ways to hit your man. Most of the levels in the game are very good about allowing for a multitude of ways to take down your target, although a couple toward the end become very linear and not that interesting in terms of strategy. As for the AI, they're pretty dang smart, I must say. They'll notice blood pools and trails and will investigate accordingly. The AI did sometimes see through my disguise even though I had done nothing wrong to blow my cover, which can be very annoying, but if you've saved fairly recently, it's not too big of a deal. Regarding saving, you can save anytime in the level (except for the highest difficulty), but the amount of times you can save per level changes with difficulty. On easy you can save as much as you want, on normal the count is 7, and on hard it's 3. This system is much better than checkpoints in my eyes given the non-linear nature of the game, but it still can be very frustrating to lose a good bit of progress just because you didn't save frequently enough. There was only one level that I found myself brushing the 7 save cap (obviously I played on Normal), but that's because there were so much man hitting to do.Apart from that, there really isn't much  else to go on about. The level design for the most part allows for many, many ways of approaching the challenge; there's plenty of tools to allow you to adapt to the scenario; the AI is for the most part very good, even on normal, and it's just a great deal of fun. 9/10.Story: A surprisingly good aspect of the game. There isn't much in the way of character development, but there's a lot of intrigue; that's for sure. Since this is my first Hitman game, I can't attest for how well it fits into the series' story arc, but it seems like a good place to wrap up the franchise, given what all happens. Without spoiling too much, I'll just say that the storyline becomes more and more tense until the final mission where things actually get pretty dang cool. If you like the Bond movies, odds are that you'll like this quite a bit as well. They definitely have a very similar feel to them. 8/10.Graphics: Oh cool, a game from 2006 that didn't abuse the hell out of bloom. Since this game goes for more of a realistic feel for the visual presentation, there isn't much sense going on about art style and all that. Rather, I'll talk about how this game would stack up against games from 2006. If you haven't guessed already, this game does a lot better than its 2006 bloom-theren. It's of course silly to ask how it holds up today; Quake 2 held up for a while until 2001 or so. For 2006, though, this game looks pretty great. As for the technical aspects of the game, I (as I just assume I'll have to do for most games) had to go into the options menu to change to a more not-terrible resolution, but it worked just fine. When you launch the game, it gives you the option to bring up a configuration menu, but I didn't find too much use for it. Beyond that, the game ran without a hitch at 1080p max settings on my GTX 760. Average temperature from a few trials was about 48degC, so it's not gonna push your hardware too hard. Overall, the graphics side of things is very good and it works great to this day. There is an issue of the realistic style dating itself, but for now at least it's still pretty nice looking. 5/5.Sound: As one would expect from such a game like this, the voice acting isn't exactly dramatic. In fact, whenever things do get hairy, Agent 47's voice acting does sound a little silly. Apart from that, the voice acting is just kinda alright, but it doesn't need to be too terribly bombastic anyways. As for the soundtrack, there's a lot of electronic music as well as orchestral music. Apparently it's a sort of blending of the prior game's soundtrack styles. Again, I can't attest for the quality of those soundtracks, but for what's presented here it's once again not bad. Not anything I'd want to go out and get the OST for, but I can at least appreciate the somewhat wide scale of the OST. Overall, on the audio front, it's not bad. Nothing too memorable, but it serves its function. 3/5.Overall scores are: 9/8/5/3; 8.3/10. I was quite pleased with this game, but I do recognise that when I eventually go back and play the prior games, they're probably not gonna be as good based solely on the fact that I played this first. Oh well; at the very least I had a good time with this one.

Posted: May 22, 2015
												This is an amazing game. You have complete freedom to complete the levels however you would like. You can go in with a mission and immediately start shooting, or you can take the approach I favor, and go in and never get seen. In this game, you become agent 47, a bald, elite Hitman clone. The goal of every mission is to take out a target or sometimes several. Sometimes, you must protect your target. Other times you must retrieve suitcases full of diamonds as well. You do all this by sneaking around, taking disguises, and silently taking everyone in your way out. The gameplay is awesome.However, the graphics leave a little to be desired, and the Glacier engine is infamous for being difficult to mod.Other things I liked: you are able to modify your weapons. This means buying nicer scopes, silencers, lockpicks, and larger clips. I also liked how funny some of the 'easter eggs' are. For example, you can knock out FBI agents by pouring ether on a bottle of panties, or poison doughnuts in order to take out a surveillance van. Overall, its a good game. Its by far the best Hitman game.

												Hitman:Blood Money is easily my most favourite stealth game ever made. The fourth instalment in the hitman series and in my opinion the best. There are many levels in this but what do you do in them; simple, Take out the targets using methods of stealth to kill or get to them. There are also a number of game difficulty stations from rookie to pro. the higher the difficulty the better the AI behavior and reactions and the less number of saves permited in a level. All in all Hitman:Blood Money has become one of my most favourite games due to it's uniqueness and choice of options. So what will you be?..... 												Everybody goes on and on about this game about how good it is, and I am one of them. Improved graphics, good story with extremely memorable levels, the ability to upgrade weapons (not all of them though, which I thought was something they should have allowed), multiple ways to complete a level, and something that I feel is the best addition to the game: it allows room for error. In previous games, enemies shot you immediately when you did something wrong, i.e tresspass. Most of the time in previous games, I didn't even know I was trespassing till I got shot several times in the face. In this game, warnings are given, not a bullet, allowing you to correct your mistake. Overall a fantastic game, can't really think of something I hate.
